title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 16
author: Various
snippet: At a fordacross the Doon, not many miles from Cassilis Castle, and still calledfrom the circumstance we are about to relate the "Gipsies' Steps," theearl and his party overtook his unfortunate countess and her still moreunfortunate seducer.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 16
author: Various
snippet: "Ye banks and braes o'bonny Doon,    How can ye bloom sae fresh and fair!    How can ye chant, ye little birds,    And I sae weary fu' o'care!"

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 16
author: Various
snippet: Thus left alone, as she oftenwas, for weeks, nay, for months, in the lonely castle in which she hadbeen immured, the Countess of Cassilis might often be seen walking onthe battlements--almost the only species of recreation within herpower--in solitary sadness; at one time stopping to gaze, but withlistless eye, on the wide and romantic scene that lay around her; atanother, to look on the leaping and foaming waters of the Doon,immortalised by the poet's song, and to think of the days that werepast, of her blighted hopes and untoward destiny.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 16
author: Various
snippet: On the day following this event, the Countess of Cassilis was removed byher husband to Cassilis Castle, an old, heavy, gloomy-looking fortaliceon the banks of the Doon, in the shire of Ayr, where the unhappy ladyremained for four years, heart-broken, crushed in spirit, and lookingforward to the grave as the only termination of her sorrows.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 16

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 05
author: Various
snippet: Nobody knew Jean betterthan Burns; and though, in his admirable poem, he places her near theDoon, yet, in fact, she was a nymph of the Carron, and a parishioner ofDurrisdeer.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 05

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 04
author: Various
snippet: "Doon wi' the man o' sin!" shouted another.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 18
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Clavers, theever-infamous, was in Wigtonshire with his Lambs; Grierson was lying inhis den of Lag, like a lion on the spring; Johnstone was on the Annan;and Winram on the Doon; whilst Douglas was here, and there, andeverywhere, flying, like a malevolent spirit, from strath to strath, andfrom hill to dale.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 18
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Clavers, theever-infamous, was in Wigtonshire with his Lambs; Grierson was lying inhis den of Lag, like a lion on the spring; Johnstone was on the Annan;and Winram on the Doon; whilst Douglas was here, and there, andeverywhere, flying, like a malevolent spirit, from strath to strath, andfrom hill to dale.

title: Greyfriars Bobby
author: Atkinson, Eleanor
snippet: "Doon wi' ye!" was the gruff order.

title: Around the clock in Europe;
author: Howell, Charles Fish.
snippet: Scotland seems unrolled at your feet and Scottish songs rush to mind until you fairly bound the region in verse and story : To the north and northwest, "Bonnie Dundee," the glens of "Clan Alpine's warriors true," Bannockburn and " Scots wha hae wi' Wallace bled," and "The Banks of Allan Water"; to the north and east, the Firth of Forth where the fishwives' " puir fellows darkle as they face the billows"; to the west and southwest, "The banks and braes o' bonnie Doon," "Tam o'Shanter's " land, " Sweet Aston" and "Bonnie Loch Leven" whence "the Camp- bells are comin'"; and to the south, "The braes of Yarrow,"  " Norham's castled steep, Tweed's fair river, broad and deep, and Cheviot's mountains lone," and, most sung of all, "The Border": —

title: Around the clock in Europe :
author: Howell, Charles Fish
snippet: Scotland seems unrolled at your feet and Scottish songs rush to mind until you fairly bound the region in verse and story : To the north and northwest, " Bonnie Dundee," the glens of "Clan Alpine's warriors true," Bannockburn and " Scots wha hae wi' Wallace bled," and "The Banks of Allan Water"; to the north and east, the Firth of Forth where the fishwives' "puir fellows darkle as they face the billows"; to the west and southwest, "The banks and braes o' bonnie Doon," " Tarn o'Shanter's " land, " Sweet Aston" and "Bonnie Loch Leven" whence "the Camp- bells are comin' "; and to the south, "The braes of Yarrow,"  "Norham's castled steep, Tweed's fair river, broad and deep, and Cheviot's mountains lone," and, most sung of all, "The Border": —

title: Fishers of men,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: " Doon yonder they'll rivet a man up in a biler for twa gallon o' Usher's best! Keep still, my mannie! Dinna be fear't — ye will be drooned lang before ye are boilt.

title: With the tourist tide,
author: Cooke, Arthur Bledsoe
snippet: The echo of the locomotive reaches down into the quiet valley where flows the bonnie Doon.

title: With the tourist tide,
author: Cooke, Arthur Bledsoe
snippet: The lover of Scotch literature feels as if he had come into the realm of story realized; for here are the very ^^banks and braes o' bonny Doon," and the waters of "sweet Aston" flowing gently among the green braes.

title: The house with the green shutters,
author: Brown, George Douglas
snippet: Doon the brae it would be," she repeated, " doon the brae it would be " — and her mind drifted away on the sorrowful future  which her fear made so vivid and real.

title: The world's best essays, from the earliest period to the present time;
author: Brewer, David J.
snippet: In outward condition and social circumstance, Hogg was more nearlv allied to Burns than to Scott; if Burns was a plowman on the banks of Doon in Ayrshire, Hogg was first a cowherd, then a shepherd, and then a farmer, first in his own native parish of Ettrick, in the highland of Selkirkshire, and afterwards on Yarrow braes, not far from the sweet pastoral seclusion  of St. Mary's Loch.

title: St. Andrews and elsewhere;
author: Boyd, Andrew Kennedy Hutchison
snippet: For that is the Doon.

title: St. Andrews and elsewhere;
author: Boyd, Andrew Kennedy Hutchison
snippet: They linger by the Doon's low trees, And pastoral Nith, and wooded Ayr ; And round thy sepulchres, Dumfries : The Poet's tomb is there !

title: Notes of foreign travel.
author: Bates, James Hale
snippet: We follow the road down to the ancient stone bridge, only a few rods distant, and leaning over the parapet, look down on the softly flowing Doon, here about 60 feet wide, its braes and banks extending up and down in the tender green of spring, dotted with daisies and musical with birds.

title: Notes of foreign travel.
author: Bates, James Hale
snippet: Bard of immortal song ! Thy same shall ever brighter grow, while Doon-
